participant id number: question asking task trial number (1-4, in order)
age group (Kids or Adults)
Age group, split into bins within children (5- to 6-year-olds, 7- to 8-year-olds, 9- to 10-year-olds, adults)
age in years (for children only)
age in months (for children only)
age in months, mean-centered (for children only)
question condition (heads = "How many monsters have a square head?", legs = "How many legs do all the monsters have combined together?"
previous quality condition (good = previously-informative, bad = previously-uninformative)
exposure condition (exposure or baseline, i.e., no-exposure)

in initial task intro, how many attempts total to identify monsters of particular color (e.g., "Can you click on the purple monster?"). Three total trials, so 3 attempts is perfect performance. Numbers greater than 3 indicate errors. Participants could make an error twice on each trial before being forced to select the correct response, so max score is 9 (three attempts on each trial, where the last attempt is a forced correct response).

in initial task intro, how many attempts total to identify monsters of particular head shape (e.g., "Can you click on the monster with a circle head?"). Two total trials, so 2 attempts is perfect performance. Numbers greater than 2 indicate errors. Participants could make an error twice on each trial before being forced to select the correct response, so max score is 6 (three attempts on each trial, where the last attempt is a forced correct response).

in initial task intro, how many attempts total to identify monsters with particular number of legs (e.g., "Can you click on the monster with two legs?"). Three total trials, so 3 attempts is perfect performance. Numbers greater than 3 indicate errors. Participants could make an error twice on each trial before being forced to select the correct response, so max score is 9 (three attempts on each trial, where the last attempt is a forced correct response).
In practice trial, what response did the participant select to answer the confederate's question?
In practice trial, what was the correct response (that the participant should have selected)?
combination of trial type (best, nonbest, overcomplex, zero) and question condition—each unique trial index is associated with a unique hint
trial type: best=best, nonbest=medium, overcomplex=too-complex, zero=worst
hint for the first monster (left) -- first is color (r=red, b=blue, p=purple), second is head shape (sq=square, cir=circle, 0 = hidden), third is number of legs (1, 2, 3, or 0=hidden)
hint for the second monster (middle) -- first is color (r=red, b=blue, p=purple), second is head shape (sq=square, cir=circle, 0 = hidden), third is number of legs (1, 2, 3, or 0=hidden)
hint for the third monster (right) -- first is color (r=red, b=blue, p=purple), second is head shape (sq=square, cir=circle, 0 = hidden), third is number of legs (1, 2, 3, or 0=hidden)
shape of the red monster's head (-1 = hidden, 1 = square, 2 = circle)
number of legs of the red monster (-1 = hidden, 1, 2, 3)
shape of the blue monster's head (-1 = hidden, 1 = square, 2 = circle)
number of legs of the blue monster (-1 = hidden, 1, 2, 3)
shape of the purple monster's head (-1 = hidden, 1 = square, 2 = circle)
number of legs of the purple monster (-1 = hidden, 1, 2, 3)
asked question
standardized text version of question (used for text-based similarity measure)
question program translation
question program translation, abstracting away free parameters
was question skipped, ambiguous, invalid, not in grammar, etc.
informativeness of asked question (expected information gain)
overall uncertainty for the present trial (max possible information gain)
Does the asked question match the target question for the heads question condition?
Does the asked question match the target question for the legs question condition?
Does the asked question match the target question based on the participant's assigned condition (heads or legs)?
Text similarity between standardized natural language questions
Tree edit distance between question programs
does this question repeat a question template used by the same participant on any previous trial?
what is the maximum degree of text similarity between the standardized question asked on this trial and all previous-trial standardized questions (excluding instances of reuse)
which previous trial indices were used for computing same_as_last (i.e., which previous trials had a valid question)
which previous trial indices were used for computing sim_to_last_standard (i.e., which previous trials had a valid question AND were not instances of reuse)
